awd_titl_txt: Photoinduced Charge-Shifting and Self-Assembly of Photochromic Polyelectrolytes
awd_abstract_narration:
There are many ways to control the properties of matter through chemical reactions.  Light is an especially unique tool for causing chemical reactions that has many advantages: it can pass through barriers such as glass, travel long distances, and be switched on and off easily. To control matter with light, a particular type of light-sensitive chemical called a photochrome is especially useful. Photochromes are molecules that change structure and color when irradiated with light.  Photochromes also changes back to their original form when the color of light is changed or the light is removed. Examples of photochromic matter are glasses that become sunglasses outdoors, but are regular glasses indoors. The research group of Professor Samuel Thomas at Tufts University investigates new forms of photochromic matter: plastics that not only change color, but also dissolve in water when irradiated with light. Because light causes photochromic molecules to switch reversibly between two structures, these polymers can then be separated from water when the light is removed, allowing for "on-demand" control over the water solubility of these plastics. This fundamental research has the potential to benefit society by opening the door to a new class of aqueous nanomaterials that harnesses the power of light to remotely control their properties for eventual utility in encapsulation and release of drugs in biomedical applications, membranes with switchable permeability, and reversible adhesives. Beyond the hands-on training that this research provides to graduate students and postdoctoral scholars, this project also provides college students from a variety of racial and ethnic backgrounds with their first experiences in original scientific research. Professor Thomas continues his successful program of recruiting students from Bunker
Hill Community College, as well as his partnerships in the Tufts Visiting and Early Research Scholars Experiences (VERSE) program, which recruits summer research students from Historically Black Colleges and Universities. 

Jointly supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry and the Polymers Program of the Division of Materials Research, this project develops a novel approach to control the properties of polyelectrolytes and enable the formation of new, self-assembled nanostructures and coacervates that undergo reversible, photoinduced phase changes as a result of charge shifting.  The first phase of this project is to establish how the structures of both spiropyran pendants on polymers and hydrophilic co-monomers influence the key properties of the photochromic units.  These properties include the acidity of protonated merocyanines, the quantum yields of merocyanine ring closures, and the rates of spiropyran openings. Measurements of photoinduced changes in solution pH and zeta potentials serve to correlate changes in optical properties to changes in polyelectrolyte charge.  The second phase of this project harnesses these systematically-derived structure-property relationships to develop reversible, photoinduced formation of polyelectrolyte nanostructures and coacervates through the corresponding changes in polymer charge at near-neutral pH. Further extension of these principles to photochromic block copolymers is aimed at reversible self-complexation and self-coacervation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Using light as a stimulus to control the properties of materials has a unique combination of advantages, such as it is possible to control with high precision where light goes, and when it goes there. We can also control the energy of light easily through its color. Finally, light can travel long distances and pass through many objects. Most light-driven reactions are irreversible: once they occur, the effect cannot be undone. In this proposal, we focused on fundamental understanding and approaches to incorporating reversible light-driven reactions reactions into organic polymers and plastics. We had three categories of key achievements:

1. Photochromic dyes are useful in applications such as transitions lenses. However, most of them share the same characteristic: their color shifts to lower energy light being absorbed when they absorb. This is how so-called "Transitions" lenses work. However, the process of "reverse photochromism"—where a stable colored form becomes colorless upon irradiation with light, is much less common. Our first published paper in this project detailed how chemical structure of electrically charged polymers influence the properties of the "reverse photochromic" structure—protonated merocyanine dyes—that are bound to the polymers. These polymers were all soluble in water, and also share the characteristic that irradiation with light not only changes their color, but also increases the acidity of the solution containing them. Among the interesting structure-property relationships we discovered through our work, the most impactful was the discovery of negatively-charged reverse-photochromic polymer that showed this effect at pH values close to neutral, instead of at highly acidic pH values. This discovery, along with our observation of no photochromic "fatigue" or degradation in performance over at least 15 cycles, improves the possibility of applications.

2. Film of poly(ethynylene oxide) (PEO) and poly(acrylic acid) (PAA), assembled one layer at a time and held together though hydrogen bonds, suffer from an extreme hygroscopic nature—exposure to humid environments can cause them to lose their shape and stiffness. We showed that we could improve the mechanical properties of these films by exposure to iron(III) ions, due to inter-chain crosslinking of the iron with carboxylate groups in PAA. Moreover, irradiating these films with UV light caused conversion of iron(III) to iron(II), which does not form strong bonds and can therefore tune the mechanical properties of the film. Re-oxidation of iron(II) to iron(III) by exposure to air restores the stiffer mechanical properties. Overall, this project revealed a simple approach for both strengthening these films with iron ions, and tuning their mechanical properties, reversibly, with light.

3. We have been able to develop polymers that contain two different units that respond to different colors of light, intended to perform different functions—one makes bonds between polymer chains, and the other breaks bonds between polymer chains. This general design - putting different light-responsive groups in series - has the potential to expand the benefits of reversible photochemical reactions into materials by integrating chemistries that are not individually reversible, but can combine to provide the benefits of reversibility.

Broader Impacts: Beyond the scientific impacts, we have made impacts in human resource development, including the training of three Ph.D. students. One graduated in 2020, and is currently employed in the chemical industry. A second is graduating in the summer of 2023, and will be a postdoctoral associate beginning in the fall. The third is an advanced Ph.D. student.


Last Modified: 06/29/2023
Modified by: Samuel Thomas
